title: German A1.2
description:
#### Learning objectives

The course is aimed at learners who have studied some basic German before, ‚Äì be it informal out-of-classroom learning, more formal in an A1.1 course or self-directed online with EDUC ‚ÄúGerman A1 Starter‚Äù. 
Built on an action-orientated approach and a fully Moodle-based online learning material, it addresses reception, production, interaction and mediation in terms of language activities in connection to language strategies in various, but typical areas of communication related to academic life in Potsdam. Consequently, it does neither claim to ‚Äúcover‚Äù the whole level A1 according to the CEFR nor to provide A1 exam training but instead to empower successful participants to take their first steps in a German speaking surrounding and ‚Äì equally important ‚Äì to manage their further language acquisition.


Upon successfully engaging in this course, learners:
- can recognise concrete information (e.g. places and times) on familiar topics encountered in everyday life, provided it is delivered slowly and clearly.
- can understand some expressions when people are discussing them: personal and academic life, hobbies or surroundings, provided the delivery is slow and clear.
- can understand instructions addressed carefully and slowly to them and follow short, simple directions.
- can understand very short, simple texts a single phrase at a time, picking up familiar names, words and basic phrases.
- can guess the probable meaning of an unknown word/sign that is similar to one in the language they normally use.
- can produce simple, mainly isolated phrases about people, time and places.
- can ask and answer simple questions, initiate and respond to simple statements in areas of immediate need or on very familiar topics.
- can make an introduction and use basic greeting and leave-taking expressions.
- can ask for food and drink using basic expressions.
- can handle numbers, quantities, cost and time (can-do statements according to the CEFR).

#### Details of the learning scenario

Mode: online synchronous via Zoom (live sessions) and online asynchronous through Moodle.

#### Schedule/Timetable of the learning offer

Starting: 20/04/2023
End: 27/07/2023
Evaluation period: TBD
Live sessions:
**Thursdays: 16:00 - 20:00 h**
prerequisites:
**This course is not suitable for beginners!** Successful applicants should be able to:
- give and ask for personal information (name, address, phone number, e-mail, study program, home university)
- talk about personal likes and dislikes 
- talk about food, buying groceries and manage orders of food and drinks in a caf√© or student canteen.

Furthermore, they should be familiar with:
- the basic concept of formal and informal German
- the basic grammar concepts of verb conjugation, noun gender, articles, nominative and accusative case, word order in sentences.

(You are welcome to explore these topics in the EDUC course [‚ÄúGerman A1 Starter‚Äù] (https://courses.educalliance.eu/course/165)  which is available for self-directed asynchronous learning on the EDUC Moodle.)


**Please only apply if you can virtually attend the sessions each week on Thursday from 4pm - 8pm.**

title: German A1 Starter
description:
#### Learning objectives

The course is suitable for learners who have never studied German before and who need a rather flexible setting which they can adjust to their own needs and prospects. By engaging in the first three chapters, learners can achieve the necessary competence level to continue learning in the synchronous German A1 course (with weekly Zoom meetings), which is also available for EDUC universities. If you would like to do the synchronous German A1 course, please allow sufficient time to complete this German A1 Starter course beforehand.

The course comprises learning objects related to typical areas of communication and basic needs in a German speaking community.  Learners can explore the material along the steps Understanding (units with language input along with reflexion exercises and linguistic explanations) Training (mainly vocab and grammar exercises), Testing (quizzes about language use) and Broadening the perspective (additional material from the internet). To ensure learners can manage without a tutor, all exercises come with either computer feedback or an answer key. 

Upon successfully engaging in this course, learners: 

- can recognise concrete information (e.g. places and times) on familiar topics encountered in everyday life, provided it is delivered slowly and clearly. 
- can understand some expressions when people are discussing them: personal and academic life, hobbies or surroundings, provided the delivery is slow and clear. 
- can understand very short, simple texts a single phrase at a time, picking up familiar names, words and basic phrases. 
- can make an introduction and use basic greeting and leave-taking expressions. 
- can ask for food and drink using basic expressions. 
- can handle numbers, quantities, cost and time (can-do statements according to the CEFR).

title: British Literature and Culture I 2023
description:
Programme Description: the lecture course for students in the BA English Studies programme offers an overview of British literature and culture from the medieval period to the beginning of the Victorian era. Its aim is to provide basic information about the socio-cultural environment in which major cultural and literary events took place. The course is held by three instructors, depending on the topic at hand. The course relies on primary readings and highly recommended reference materials, which are made available online for students.
General objectives: students completing this survey course will 
--have an overview of British literary history from the Middle Ages to the Victorian period, 
--improve their analytic skills through the exploration of connections between literary texts and their different historical, social and cultural contexts, 
--be better equipped for the analysis of literary texts in a variety of genres, 
--learn about the emergence and early history of literary genres popular today, 
--make a connection between current cultural, medial and literary events and trends, and their literary-historical precedents. 
Short-term achievements: by attending the lecture course, students will gain information on the best canonical writers, their works, and the historical and cultural contexts of the discussed literary periods. The assessment of the course will be based on a final written exam covering the topics discussed during the sessions as well as the primary readings.
Long-term achievements: the course is an essential part of the English Studies BA programme. Teaching literary histories is part of the curricula of English Studies programmes in BA courses in Europe. We plan to reach undergraduate students from the universities participating in the EDUC consortium. The lecture course will contribute to their knowledge of English literary and cultural studies of which this lecture course on British Literature and Culture I is an essential part. 

Teachers: Dr. Gabriella Hartvig (University of P√©cs), Dr. Filip Bul Krajn√≠k (Masaryk University Brno), Dr. Csaba Maczelka (University of P√©cs)

title: European Criminal Law (EUCRIM) 2023
description: Our pedagogical team from the Masaryk University, theUniversity of Potsdam, the University of Cagliariand the University of P√©cs aims to create a course which provides thorough  understanding  of  the  topic  of European criminal law ‚Äìone of the fastest developing EU policies. The topic is quite extensive: it involves the traditional issue of transnational organised crime and how to tackle it (as such legal instruments of operative cooperation  of  law  enforcement  and  judicial  authorities  of  EU  Member  States and  the  harmonisation  of substantive criminal law shall be presented as indispensable tools in EU criminal law). However,the speedy technological advancement created issues that did not exist in the past ‚Äìor at least not to such an extent as today. As such the course also involves an in-depth analysis of cybercrime and EU criminal law designed to tackle  it  (among  others  the  European Production  Order  and  the  European  Preservation  Order  will  be introduced in the course). Last, but not least the protection of fundamental rights must be emphasised since EU criminal law is a policy area which greatly affects the freedom of EU citizens (in this context the principle of mutual trust, the ne bis in idem principleand the practice of the Court of Justice of the European Union shall be presented).\n\nTimetable: 17 February ‚Äì 20 May 2023 - on Thursdays and Fridays 9.00 or 10.00 CET (9.00: 9 March, 16 March; 10.00: 17 February, 23 February, 3 March, 24 March, 31 March, 14 April, 21 April, 28 April, 4 May)

title: Introduction to data analysis: data processing, statistics and visualization
description:
#### Learning objectives

This course on data analysis with Python will cover the fundamental concepts and techniques needed to manipulate, explore and visualise data using the Python programming language and some popular libraries and packages, such as NumPy, Pandas and Matplotlib.

At the end of the course, students will have a solid understanding of Python's data analysis capabilities and the skills necessary to manipulate, explore, and visualize data effectively using libraries such as NumPy, Pandas, and Matplotlib.

title: Memorable Speaking: Making an Impact (English Oral Proficiency II)
description:
#### Learning objectives

What makes a speech memorable? In this collaborative online international learning (COIL) project between the University of Potsdam and Beit Berl College (Israel),  students listen to and learn from noted speakers in the fields of business, politics, literature, and education. In turn, students share their ideas on these topics by making memorable speeches of their own. We welcome students from the EDUC alliance to participate in some of the sessions (**for no ECTS points**).
Please see "More Info" for the course time, expected outcomes, and requirements .)

title: Writing Across Cultures (English Academic Writing II) (Summer 2023)
description:
#### Learning objectives

Taking the UNESCO working paper "Intercultural Competence: Conceptual and Operational Framework" (Leeds-Hurwitzand Stenou, 2013) as a springboard, we investigate the meaning and relevance of intercultural competence in today's world. Students then research and write about a topic of their choosing that is related to intercultural competence. Exercises that develop students' peer review skills will help them to identify and correct errors in their peers' and in their own writing. We view writing squarely as a process and consequently do portfolio work over the course of the semester. The semester culminates in a short presentation of the students' essays.
We welcome students in the EDUC alliance to participate in some of the sessions (**for no ECTS points**).

This two-hour writing course centers on essay writing and the argumentative essay in particular. Upon completion of this course, students will be able
- to express themselves using nuanced language (improved accuracy and appropriacy of writing)
- to produce cohesive and coherent academic writing (improved complexity and effectiveness of writing)
- to identify and produce various types of academic texts
- to evaluate their own and others' texts (peer review)
- to assess and cite (MLA) appropriate sources properly

Students are strongly encouraged to consult with the Writing Assistance Program at Zessko (this is not a course tutorial).

title: On-line Education of the Limb Anatomy (Autumn 2023)
description:
#### Learning objectives

The content of the course is practical teaching of bones, joints, muscular system, vascular supply, innervation and regional anatomy of the limbs and back.

At the end of the course participants will:
- be able to name the anatomical structures of the passive and active locomotor system;
- can explain the importance of attachment structures on bones, mechanics, movements in joints and the function of muscle groups;
- students should be able to assess the normal state of the musculoskeletal system as opposed to the pathological state.

#### Details of the learning scenario

This learning offer is asynchronous, which means that students work with on-line materials and fill out on-line tests.

Please consider a work-load per week of: 2-3 hours (50 hours per the whole course)

title: Career project preparation for French-speaking students (Autumn 2023)
description:
#### Learning objectives

The course is based on the analysis of authentic documents. Students are familiarized with the general principles of written communication and with the formal requirements of business correspondence in French. Creation of the written documents based on their models (CV and cover letter) and job interview preparation. Thanks to the internationalisation aspects of the course, the aims are also to share and discuss career projects possibilities with students from foreign universities (from France and Hungary) and to develop intercultural competence and open-mindedness.

At the end of the course participants will:
- differentiate different types of business correspondence documents, 
- understand their statement, 
- create their own written documents (CV and cover letter), 
- apply the knowledge and skills in practice, 
- discuss their career projects, skills and competencies, 
- talk about their experience from project work in an international team.
